rev.comment: Reverted to revision 360590353 by [[Special:Contributions/Agent4453|Agent4453]]; The new logo is not the company's official logo. See [[Talk:Google]].. ([[WP:TW|TW]])

Line 67: Line 67:
===Advertising===
===Advertising===
â
[[Image:Google.png|thumb|left|old Google logo]]
 
Ninety-nine percent of Google's revenue is derived from its advertising programs.<ref>Google Annual Report, Feb. 15, 2008</ref> For the 2006 fiscal year, the company reported $10.492 billion in total advertising revenues and only $112 million in licensing and other revenues.<ref name="10-K">{{cite web|url=http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1288776/000119312507044494/d10k.htm|title=Form 10-K â Annual Report|accessdate=2007-07-14|publisher=SEC|work=EDGAR}}</ref> Google has implemented various innovations in the online advertising market that helped propel them to one of the biggest advertisers in the market. Using technology from the company [[DoubleClick]], Google can determine user interests and target advertisements appropriately so they are relevant to the context they are in and the user that is viewing them.<ref>{{cite news|author=Nakashima, Ellen|title=Some Web Firms Say They Track Behavior Without Explicit Consent|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/11/AR2008081102270_pf.html|date=August 12, 2008|publisher=The Washington Post Company|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Helft, Miguel|title=Google to Offer Ads Based on Interests |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/11/technology/internet/11google.html|publisher=The New York Times|date=March 11, 2009|accessdate=2009-03-10}}</ref> [[Google Analytics]] allows website owners to track where and how people use their website, allowing for in-depth research into getting users to go where you want them to go.<ref>{{cite news|author=Bright, Peter|title=Surfing on the sly with IE8's new "InPrivate" Internet|url=http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20080827-surfing-on-the-sly-ie8s-inprivate-internet.html|date=August 27, 2008|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref>
Ninety-nine percent of Google's revenue is derived from its advertising programs.<ref>Google Annual Report, Feb. 15, 2008</ref> For the 2006 fiscal year, the company reported $10.492 billion in total advertising revenues and only $112 million in licensing and other revenues.<ref name="10-K">{{cite web|url=http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1288776/000119312507044494/d10k.htm|title=Form 10-K â Annual Report|accessdate=2007-07-14|publisher=SEC|work=EDGAR}}</ref> Google has implemented various innovations in the online advertising market that helped propel them to one of the biggest advertisers in the market. Using technology from the company [[DoubleClick]], Google can determine user interests and target advertisements appropriately so they are relevant to the context they are in and the user that is viewing them.<ref>{{cite news|author=Nakashima, Ellen|title=Some Web Firms Say They Track Behavior Without Explicit Consent|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/11/AR2008081102270_pf.html|date=August 12, 2008|publisher=The Washington Post Company|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Helft, Miguel|title=Google to Offer Ads Based on Interests |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/11/technology/internet/11google.html|publisher=The New York Times|date=March 11, 2009|accessdate=2009-03-10}}</ref> [[Google Analytics]] allows website owners to track where and how people use their website, allowing for in-depth research into getting users to go where you want them to go.<ref>{{cite news|author=Bright, Peter|title=Surfing on the sly with IE8's new "InPrivate" Internet|url=http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20080827-surfing-on-the-sly-ie8s-inprivate-internet.html|date=August 27, 2008|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref>
